; about the 12th of August this person came to me in the bar, between three and four o'clock, as nigh as I can guess; he came and had a glass of Hollands, and he gave me a shilling, and I thought it was a good one, and I put it down and changed it, and he went out; about five minutes after a woman came in and had a glass of shrub, and she gave me a shilling to change, and I looked at it and thought it might be a good one; she said I might give her all half-pence in change.
Q. Did you see the prisoner again that day? - I did not; my mistress was out.

Q. What did you do with that shilling that he gave you? - I laid it down very curiously in the till, and I wrapped it up in a bit of paper till she came in. About the 3d of September the prisoner came in again, between three and four or four and five, I cannot positively say, and asked for a glass of Hollands, and he gave me a shilling; it was a plain one; I refused it because I thought it was a bad one, and he gave me another, which was a crooked one, and that I gave change for; I have got it here; I have kept it ever since.
Q. What did you do with the first shilling? - I gave it him back.
Q. What happened after that? - The woman came in as usual about five minutes afterwards; my master came out to me about the time the woman came in, and he went after the prisoner immediately.
Mr. Knapp. On the 3d of September the prisoner gave you a plain one? - He did; I thought it was a bad one.
Q. And then he gave you this? - Yes.
Mr. Gullon. What did you do with the money that was tendered to you on the 25th of August? - I have got it here.

WILLIAM FRENCH
sworn.

I keep a public house in Warwick-lane; on the 3d of September the bar maid gave me a shilling, which had been tendered to her by the prisoner at the bar; she knew that I had ordered this man to be taken into custody the next time he came to the house. I followed him, took him, and charged a constable with him; I see him at the corner of Paternoster-row; there I see him and collared him, and ordered a corman to follow me. I asked him if there was not a lady waiting for him at that house? he said he knew no lady; and when he was brought back they did not know one another at all. I keep the White Horse in Warwick-lane.

Q. You produce three shillings; where did you get them from? - From the bar maid. We had suspicion of some utterers of bad money using the house, from the vast quantity of bad silver that kept creeping into the till.

DAVID HUGHES
sworn.

I am a constable. I took the prisoner into custody the 3d of September, at the White-house, in Warwick-lane. I searched; I found no bad money on him; he had two or three shillings, some sixpences, and half a crown, a guinea, and some halfpence, I found some bad on the woman, Hannah Burley.
Mr. Knapp. All the money you found on him was good? - It was, and I returned it again.
Court to Bedford. Did you see the man and woman in the house together? - Never.

THOMAS BADER
sworn.

I was present when Mr. French took the prisoner by the collar; I am servant to Mr. Batterworth, on Holborn-bridge. The prisoner was leaning on the post, by the corner of Paternoster-row; there was another with me. Mr. French comes up and says, I want you two to assist me to take a thief; Ithought he was only joking, but I see him pass by, and seize the prisoner by the collar, and led him towards his own house; and as the prisoner was going, he put his right hand into his right hand breeches pocket, and he threw away a quantity of silver into the kennel. I kept my eye on it, and went to it immediately, and kneeled down, and picked up a shilling, which here it is. One of Mr. French's servants put his hand into the water, and he found two shillings; that shilling I picked up I marked, I can swear to it.
Mr. Knapp. You always said they were shillings that he threw out of his hands? - It was white, and it appeared to me to be silver.
Q. Did you say before the justice that the prisoner threw away silver? - I cannot say.
Q. Why did you say before the magistrate that you see the prisoner throw away something, but what it was you could not tell? - Please your Worship I do not recollect it.
Court. Whatever he threw away you picked up? - Yes, I did.

JOHN HALL
sworn.
I am servant to Mr. French. I found two shillings in the kennel, here they are, I marked them myself.

WILLIAM PARKER
sworn.
These three shillings are all bad, found in the kennel, and the one shilling he tendered.
Mr. Knapp. Are you sure of that? - Yes, I am; it is a very good one as a bad one.(Mr. Knapp addressed the jury on the part of the desendant.)
GEORGE HEMELEY sworn.
I am a Lieutenant of his Majesty's Navy, on half-pay. I have known the prisoner for six or seven years; I never heard any thing against him in my life.
Court. What is he? - An artificial flower maker; I have had dealings with him in that line.
Q. Where do you live? - In Tottenham-court road, Sloane-street. I fell there to the Captains of ships.
Q. How long since is it that you was in actual service? - In 83, in the Sevile frigate, with Lord George Fitzgerald.
The prisoner called two other witnesses to his character.
GUILTY .

Imprisoned six months in Newgate , and to find
security for twelve months .
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. COMMON SERGEANT.

568.
THOMAS SIMMONS
and
WILLIAM BOOTH
were indicted, for
feloniously and burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling house of
John Willan
, in the parish of Christ Church
, about the hour of two in the night, of the 16th of September , and burglariously stealing therein, ten pieces of woollen cloth, value 60l. his goods .
The Case was opened by Mr. Raine.

JOHN WILLAN
sworn.

Q.
What are you? - I keep the Bull and Mouth inn .

Q. And as we all know a considerable coach master there. Had you any quantity of cloth in your custody on Tuesday, the 16th of this month? - Yes, I had four bales of broad cloth, but there was only one removed.
Q. The exact quantity of this particular bale you don't know, I suppose? -
Court. Is your warehouse within the gates of your yard? - It is.
Mr. Raine. Do you know the quantity nearly that is in this bale? - Ten pieces, about one hundred and fifty yards, as near as I can guess.
Q. Where was this deposited? - In the warehouse, which is over the stable.
Q. Will you describe the situation of this warehouse? - All the buildings adjoins, and this warehouse was connected with other warehouses, which join my house.
Court. If I understand you right, there are gates to that yard? - Yes.
Q. In that yard one side is the stables, over which is the warehouses, and the other side is your dwelling house? - Yes.
Mr. Knowlys. Who else, within this court yard, is in partnership with you? - Not any concerned in the business.
Q. There are some other persons that live in the same yard with you? - None but tenants to me, who keep the tavern business.
Q. Are there not other persons accountable for the loss of these things besides yourself? - No.
Q. Is there none of your own family concerned with you? - None.
Q. You pay rates? - Yes.
Q. In what parish? - In two parishes.
Q. In what parish was this warehouse, where this cloth was removed? - It stands in both parishes.
Q. In what parish is that part of the warehouse, from whence the cloth was taken? - In Christ Church.
Q. Are you sure of that? - It divides in the warehouse, but the locks that were broke open were most certainly in the parish of Christ Church.
Q. I want to know whe ther that part of the warehouse, from whence these goods were removed, was not in St. Botolph, Aldersgate? - I believe myself it is in Christ Church parish.
Court It is perfectly indifferent in what parish.

ALEXANDER PYCRAFT
sworn.
I am servant to Mr. Willan; I locked the door last Tuesday sevennight, in the evening, between eight and nine o'clock.
Q. What door did you lock? - The great door of the stable, and the little door that leads into the street.
Q. Did you lock this door, that was afterwards broke open? - Yes, between eight and nine.

Q. Who did you give the keys to? - I carried the keys to
Richard Beck
's bed side, where I used to carry them. I am sure I locked it.
Q. What door was this that was broke open? - The door of the stable.

RICHARD BECK
sworn.
I am servant to Mr. Willan.

Q. You have heard from the last witness that he deposited the keys of Mr. Willan's doors last Tuesday sevennight with you? - He did. I was alarmed in the course of that night; about one I got up, and brought the keys down, and I went to the warehouse door, and found the stable door open; the back gate was undone, and the lock lay down behind the gate; I picked the lock up.
Q. What else did you observe? - Nothing more but people in the street.
Q. Did you look at the stable door? - Yes; that was locked, I unlocked it.

MARY WOODMAN
sworn.
I am a single woman; I live in Bulland Mouth-street; I live at the corner of Mr. Willian's gateway.

Q. About ten o'clock at night on last Tuesday sevennight do you recollect observing any men come there? - Yes; I observed five, I see them walking backwards and forwards in the street, and taking great notice of the Bull and Mouth inn; and I went in doors, and when I came out again I went of an errand, it was between nine and ten; I saw two of them at the top of the street, and one of them said to the other, it will not do to night, and the other said, yes, it will, but it must be later. To the best of my knowledge Booth is one of them.
Q. Did you notice him particularly? - I think he is one.
Court. Had you an opportunity to observe him? - Yes.
Q. What did you take notice of, the dress or the face? - I took such notice as I think I should know him again.
Q. How was he dressed? - In much the same dress as he s now; I think he had a light coat on the night that I see him.
Q. What waistcoat? - I did not take notice. I thought he was after the Bull and Mouth inn; I had seen several men, for above a fortnight, taking notice of the Bull and Mouth inn.
Q. Did you know him before? - Yes.
Q. Had you seen him before? - Yes, I see him the Friday before in Aldersgate-street, him and a tall man, walking backward and forward.
Q. Is it a belief that you are almost certain; only you don't choose to swear to him? - Yes.
Q. Have you any doubt in your mind? - I have do doubt but he is the person.

Q. You say you saw five men talking together. Are you sure that the men that you saw afterwards, at the top of the street, were two of these five? - Yes, I am; three of them went down the street, and two went up.
Mr. Raine. What time did you go to bed? - Between ten and eleven.
Q. Were you disturbed? - Yes; I did not hear nothing at all about it, only my father did.

Mr. Knapp. This was a dark night, past nine o'clock, and you had never seen the person before. Did not you state, be fore my Lord Mayor, that the person of Booth was dressed exactly as he is now? - Not to my knowledge, I don't think I did.
Q. This was a dark night? - Not a very dark night.
Q. The moon was in its last quarter I believe? Pray, in what line of life are you in? - I live with my father and mother.
Q. In Bull and Mouth street? - Yes, my father is a shoemaker, and I work at the binding of shoes.
Q. Do you live at home? - Yes.

Q. I would ask you again what my Lord asked you just now; consider, this man's life is at stake; and tell the jury whether you can take upon yourself to swear that he is the man? - No, I don't wish to swear.

Mr.
Raine Do
you mean to say what you said before to my Lord Mayor, that you have no doubt but he is the man? - I have no doubt.
Court. You was examined several times before the Lord Mayor? - Yes.
Q. Was you as positive at your first examination as you was afterwards to the man? - To the best of my knowledge I was.

Q. That is a fact you must recollect, because they were taken up soon after the robbery. You spake then as you do now, of five men; was you as positive to these men being two of that five as you are now? - Yes, I was.
Q. Did not you hesitate? - I don't think I did.
Q. It is a very material point, because where it depends on identity of a person,it is very material to know whether you was at all times as positive? - Yes.
Q. Are you sure of it? - Yes.
Q. Had you never any doubt on your mind? - Never. When I went in before the Lord Mayor, my father said, now, look round, and see if you know either of these young men; and I looked at Booth directly.
Were they in irons? - The other had, but not Booth.

PHILIP STANHOPE
sworn.

Q. Do you recollect any thing passing at Mr. Willan's last Tuesday sevennight, at night? - On Wednesday morning, about two o'clock, I had had some difference with my family, which kept me up till that late hour; I went up then to go to bed, and I went to my window to shut it down, and I observed two men standing by the side of Mr. Willan's door, directly I see one of them open it, as if he had a key to it; directly I see another man come out, as if he came to my door, and I heard an expression, it will do, George.

Q. Who said that? - I cannot take on me to say. With that it struck me there was no good going on there; I see three of them enter the stable, and they immediately fastened the door after them; there was another seemed to watch outside. I continued to watch, and I heard them pass through the stable to a pair of gates that is a little above the stable; I thought I heard the bar of the gates taken down, the found was like the found of the bar being moved; I then soon after saw a light in the lost, pass backwards and forwards, over the stable, in a warehouse above, where the goods are deposited; I then thought that they meant to rob, and I watched an opportunity to get out, that was when the watchman came down the street, about half after one, and the man walked away. I should inform you, that the man that was watching got up to the lost door, and peeped through, and seemed to me as if he spoke something, but I drew back, because he should not see me. When the watchman came, I went out.

Q. How did he get up to this door? - By means of the window, where the bars are underneath; he got up as far as the window by means of the bars. I went out, and told the watchman what I had seen, and asked him what he should do; he seemed to hesitate, that it was out of his beat; I told him he must not stand about beats in such a case as that; I told him to wait there, while I went down and alarmed the inn; and I went down and alarmed the inn. I knocked at the gate, and told the porter that opened the gate; he is the chamberlain or porter. I waited some time watching; when the three men that I see go in rushed out at the gate, where they had taken down the bar; I immediately ran after them, and pursued them, and I cried out, Stop thief; and the last man cried out, Stop thief likewise. When I came within three or four yards of the last, he was then turning the passage that leads into Little Britain, as he turned round he fired a pistol right at me, which alarmed me very much, and rather struck me so that I could go no further; it was two or three minutes before I recovered myself, and the watchman came up, and sprung his rattle. I lost fight of him then; I then ran down into Little Britain, and the watchman had got the prisoner Booth in custody. I ran the way that I supposed he ran that fired at me.
Q. How far was he gone in Little Britain? - He was at the bottom of the Britain, I suppose it may be about one hundred yards.
Q. What was become of the watchman that was with you? - He followed after, I believe, and assisted.
Q. You had no opportunity of seeingthe face of the man that you followed? - No, I did not.

Q.
You don't know as to his person at all? - I cannot identify his person; when he was in custody of the watchman he was very much confused; he said he was pursuing the thieves, and that he belonged to the inn, and that his master had been robbed. They then took him to the watch-house.

Mr. Knapp. If I understand you right, you did not mean to speak, nor never did mean to speak, to the person of the man, whoever he was; and the pistol was not tried till he came into Little Britain? - No; is was fired at the entrance of the passage, at the top of Bull and Mouth-street.
Q. There was no pistol found on Booth, I believe? - Not that I understand; there was a search made, and none found.
Court. Was there any body running between you and the prisoner? - I saw no body at all.

ELIZABETH STANHOPE
sworn.
I am wife to the last witness. I live in Bull and Mouth-street, opposite Mr. Willan's.

Q. Was you at your door at one o'clock the night of last Tuesday sevennight? - Yes. Mr. Stanhope and I had a little difference, and I went to the door, because I would have no more words; and there were three men came past, and one of them said to me, what do you stay here for? I said, that was my business, and not their's. I think Simmons was one, but I could not swear to him, because it was moon light, and not so very light for me to swear to him. He asked me why I did not go in? I said I should when I pleased; and told him to go about his business. He asked me if I had lived there long? I told him eight or nine years; he then asked me if I knew old Mr. King, the grocer? and I told him, that I believed he dropped off his horse at Islington; he said that was right. He asked me if I knew Mr. King's son? I said yes; and he asked me if knew the opposite King? I told him yes. He asked me if I knew Mr. Wilson? I told him I knew every one in the street; and then Mr. Stanhope desired me to go in, and I went in, and shut the door, and the dog was out, and scratched at the door, and I went to let him in; and the noise of the door induced Mr. Stanhope to look out of window, and he came down stairs, and desired I would come up and see, for he was sure somebody had gone into Mr. Willan's place; and when I went up stairs, I see the light below, where the horses were, and I heard a kind of a bar taken down from the large gates, and then I see the light afterwards in the lost above, and the light, came up to the far end of the lost, which is the warehouse, a very great light, and then Mr. Stanley said, he would not stop any longer; and he ran down stairs. I said he had better stop a little, for the watchman was coming, and I would tell him; then he went up the street, and met the watchman about No. 17; he said it was not his beat - My husband went and alarmed the men of the inn; and in the course of that time there were three men came out of the gate; I see them come out, and they ran up the street towards Little Britain. When they came out, I cried out, Stop thief.

Q. When they came out had you an opportunity of observing them? - I had not of the two first, but I had of the last. I believe that to be Booth; I think so; then I heard the report of the pistol; and the man that was the last made a slip, and something like a pistol struck, and I saw a flash come from it; and then he ran up the street, and there was the report of another; and then Mr. Stanhope drawed back.

Q.
Whereabouts was the man when you heard the report? - At the gateway; it flashed in the pan, it did not go off; I did not see any thing more of them till they were taken.
Q. Had you observed any more people abou there? - No, I did not see any thing but a man without, that got up and whiltled to them through the bars, at the left door.
Q. Then you believe the last man was Booth? - I believe so, I am not quite certain.
Q. I take it for granted you had an opportunity of observing his face? - I see his side face, but not to know him again when he came out.
Q. From what you see you believe it to be Booth? - Yes.
Q. You was standing at the door, conversing with Simmons about five minutes. How far was you from him? - About the distance I stand from you; he stood across the kennel, behind the gate.

Q.
Then you do not mean to say positively that Simmons is the man, but you believe him to he the man? - I do.
Mr. Knowlys. Whoever was the person that was talking to you, he went down the street? - He did, towards St. Martin's-le-grand.
Court. You speak of four men; three that were in the stable, and one that was outside; did you know him that was outside? - No, I could not know him again.
Mr. Knowlys. How came you to be standing at the door at that time of the morning? - My husband and I had a few words.

Q. This was in Bull and Mouth-street; there are some gentlemen in the city that know that street better than I do; I don't live in the city. At one o'clock in the morning you was standing at the door; was your husband in bed? - He was standing at that time with the street door in his hand, intreating me to come in.

Q.
He was not up stairs at all at the window? - No, not till he shut the door, and opened it again to let the dog in.
Q. At the time this past, your husband was standing with the door in his hand? - He was.
Q. How many inches happened your husband to be from you at the time you had this conversation with Simmons? - If I had a person standing by, taking measure, I might have known it.
Q. Your husband was as close perhaps behind you as that gentleman is before you? - He was behind; I believe he might.
Q. Then he must have heard all this conversation between you and Simmons? - I dare say if you ask him he will tell you.
Q. This person that may or may not be Simmons, he asked you if you knew Mr. King? and he was as far off as this gentleman by my side? - He was.
Q. He spoke loud enough for you to hear what he said to you? - Certainly.
Q. Your husband was behind you as close as that gentleman is before you? - If you will come to the purpose I will answer you; I did not come here to talk family affairs.
Q. Then this person said, does Mr. King live here? - No; he asked me if I knew King? and what then, that is not to the purpose.

Q. When he asked you if Mr. King lived there, what answer did you make him? - He did not ask me that; he asked me if I knew him? I said I believed he was dead. I said, yes. Then he asked me if knew Mr. Wilson? I said, yes; and I said I knew every one in the street.

Q.
Then I suppose your husband called out to you to shut the door? - He did not.
Q. Did he take any notice of this conversation? - He did not indeed.

THOMAS MAC EWEN
sworn.
I am a watchman; I stand in Little Britain.
Q. In the morning of last Tuesday sevenight was you alarmed with the report of a pistol? - I was, about a quarter after two.
Q. What did you first observe? - The first alarm was the pistol going off; I made towards where I heard it go off, towards Bull and Mouth-street, and the other watchman cried out stop thief!

Q. You sprung your rattle? - Yes, I did, when I heard them cry out stop thief! The other watchman's name is Richard Earling. With that the young man comes running crying stop thief! stop thief!
Thomas Booth
, the man nearest to me this side.
Q. Was he running towards you? - He was.
Q. How near was he to you when you first see him? - He was as good as half way down the Britain towards me, coming from towards Bull and Mouth-street.

Q. When he came towards you what did he say? - I told him he should stop. He said it was a young man that was breaking into his master's place. I told him I did not care, he was the first man I met, and he should stop.
Mr. Knapp. Booth was running towards you, a watchman? - He was running towards me.

Q.
Was it dark? - I could not see the shade of the moon, I did observe him coming towards me.
Q. You took him to the watch house? - Yes.
Q. He was searched and nothing found on him? - Nothing but two knives.
Q. What coloured coat had Booth on? - A blue; I am sure of it.
Mr. Knowlys. You said you could not see any moon light; if there was any moon at all the height of the house quite impeded you from seeing any thing of this sort.
Mr. Raine. Was he running towards down Little Britain from Bull and Mouth-street? - He was.

WILLIAM CHILD
sworn.

I am a watchman; my stand is in Newgate-street. In the night of last Tuesday sevenight, or Wednesday morning, I was alarmed by a pistol at the bottom of Butcherhall-lane, which goes into Bull and Mouth-street; after that I heard a watchman's rattle go, there was another watchman just by me, one Duckham, he and I went down Butcherhall-lane to see where the report came from: we had not gone above twenty or thirty yards, or forty, before Duckham met the prisoner Simmons at the bar.

Q. Was he running? - No; Duckham asked the prisoner where that alarm of the rattle was? he answered it was below; on which Duckham let him pass; and he came on to me and I stopped him, and immediately as we were leading him up to Butcherhall-lane he began searching his pockets. I says to Duckham, mind be drops nothing; and he said no, I am not going to drop any thing; and we took him to the constable of the night at the watch house.

THOMAS DUCKHAM
sworn.

I am a watchman in Newgate-street. On Wednesday morning sevenight early I was standing at the end of my beat, and my other partner was standing just by his, I heard a pistol fire, or a gun, I don't know which; I said to my partner there is something a matter below; we went down as fast as we could; we had not gone above a hundred yards before we met the prisoner at the bar, the man at the right, Simmons, I said, where is that rattle sprung? the prisoner says below. My partner being just behind me, said, perhaps you are the man, and took hold of me. I turned round directly and said, very possibly you are; he wasintimidated indeed, very much shocked, and we afterwards conveyed him to the watch-house. He began to shuffle his pockets, as if he meant to throw something out; we don't know that he did. We took him to the watch-house, and then we came down to Mr. Willan's, in order to learn what the alarm was, there we learnt the occasion; we learnt that they had broke into Mr. Willan's apartment, and that they had escaped the minute or two before.

RICHARD EARLING
sworn.
I am a watchman; my station is in Little Britain.
Q. You heard the alarm early on Wednesday morning, yesterday seven night? - Yes, about a quarter after two; and I started out directly, and I saw two men by the post, and there was a pistol fired.
Q. Did you see the pistol go off? - Yes.

Q. Where are these posts? - Going up to Bull and Mouth-street, that way. I stepped up directly and caught one by the collar, that was Booth; he made answer and said, not me, take the other: with that he got somehow or other from my hand, and I called out stop thief! and he called out likewise; and I called out to my partner that was below to stop that man, for I believe he was one of the people.

Q. Who was the partner that you called out to? -
Mac Ewen
. He was stopped, and I came up to him and aided and assisted in taking him to the watch-house.
Q. Did you lose sight of the prisoner till he was stopped? - No; he was not out of my sight all the time.
Mr. Knapp. The pistol was fired in Little Britain? - Yes, close to the posts.

Q.
What was the colour of Booth's coat when he was taken? - I am sure he had a blue one on.

Court. Are you sure that the person that fired the pistol was the person that you collared? - I cannot take upon myself to say which of the men it was; the other man ran up towards Butcherhall-lane way; there was none past me at all but this man.
Q. How soon did you see Stanhope? - I cannot say, for I went directly to the watch-house with the prisoner we had got, I and my partner.
Q. Did you search him? - The officer did when we carried him to the watchhouse.
Q. Did you find any pistol? - No.
Q. Did you search? - Yes; we came back and looked about the place, but could find none.
EDGATE ATKINSON sworn.
I am a harness maker; I live opposite the Bull and Mouth Inn.
Q. I believe you are employed by Mr. Willan about his premises, the Bull and Mouth? - I am.
Q. Did you examine the warehouse? - Tuesday evening before it was broke open I did, about seven o'clock; I was working all that day, and when I left work it was about seven o'clock.

Q. Did you see the bales there deposited? - I did, three; one was deposited close to the warehouse door, a little on one side, on the left hand side of the door, and the other two were deposited to it against the front wall; they were perfectly safe packed with strong cordage.

WILLIAM WORSTER
sworn.
I am servant to Mr. Willan. Early on Wednesday morning, about two o'clock, when the alarm was given, I observed a pack cut open. I did not go into the warehouse the same way the theves broke in.

Q. Whereabouts was that bale of goods which you see cut open? - At the end of the lost near to the harness maker's room; they had taken the cloth, almost the whole of it within three parcels of that bale, and carried it to the further end of the lost towards the door, near the stairs.
Q. Did you happen to know where this particular bale had been deposited the night before? - I cannot say that.
Q. Where were the other two bales? - They were standing at the right hand of it. There was a place cut with a knife in one of the others.
Q. Where was the wrapper that contained this cloth? - The wrapper stood where the bale was cut open.
Q. What distance was the cloth that was taken out from the wrapper that had contained the cloth? - About forty yards.
Q. What else did you observe in the warehouse? - I found a dark lanthorn, a black bag, and an iron crow made out of an old file; I delivered these things to the constable who is at the door now.
Q. Had you observed where the persons came in? - I cannot say I did.
Q. You say you did not go in the way you believe the thieves came in? - I did not; I believe they came in at a place called the Dunghill Gate.

GABRIEL JOHNSON
sworn.

I am a constable; the last witness delivered to me the things he found in the warehouse, a bag, a dark lanthorn, and a crow; I marked the bag, and Woodman took it down to Simmons's mother-in-law; I cut it on the top with a knife.

JAMES WOODMAN
sworn.
This bag was delivered to me by the last witness, and I carried it down to Cow-Cross; and after I took it to the Lord Mayor, and then the officer who gave the last evidence, he took it.

SUSANNA COLEMAN
sworn.
Q. Did you ever see this bag before? - I see a bit of black cloth before.

Q. Mrs. Coleman, now mind, I warn you that you speak the truth; recollect that you are sworn, and that you have been on your oath before; you have given evidence on your oath, and I am going to examine to the same facts; if you deviate, if you don't swear to what is the truth exactly, you may hear of it hereafter.

Court. You are called here to give your evidence on oath, and you are told that you have been examined before, therefore a caution is given you to speak the truth; if you prevaricate and do not speak the truth you will be liable to be punished, both here and hereafter, therefore let this be a caution; perhaps you are going to say now what may be the truth, perhaps what you said before may be the truth; you stand there in a very suspicious light, therefore now be cautious.

Mr.
Raine Look
at that bag; do you know that bag? examine it carefully woman, look at it? - I don't know.
Q. I don't ask you yet? - Yes, sir, I believe it may be the bag; but I never see it open till I see it open at the house it come from, at Cow-Cross.

Q. That was subsequent to this robbery? - A gentleman came on Saturday morning and said, is Mr. Simmons at home? and directly asked if he was a hatter? I shewed him his work shop, and all his tools. He said he was sorry for him to be in trouble, he would soon be out, it was only for an assault, or quarrel; he came again in about half an hour, and said, I have been to the Mansion House, and he said, I am all of a muck sweat; he untied a black thing in the handkerchief, and said to the mother, do you know this black bag? if you wouldcome and speak to it your son will soon be released out of trouble.
Woodman. I never said such a word.

Coleman. His mother said she could not leave the shop; then the mother said to me, you go and speak for him: she directly said she believed it was the boy's bag, or cloth. I went with the gentleman, and he took a coach and took me to the Hall. I came before the Lord Mayor, and I said, when is this poor man to be released? he said never mind, you will be paid for your trouble. He came with this bag before the Lord Mayor, and I said I had seen a black cloth under the bed, the gentlewoman's bed, but I never see it open in my life.
Q. Now you are sure that that man that stands by you said, that if you come and swear to this bag that this young man would be released? - I would not take a false oath for my life and soul.
Q. Then how came you to swear to the bag before the Lord Mayor? - The old woman said that she believed it was her son's.

Q. Did you tell my Lord Mayor that story as you do now? - I said the very same; I think I said what I say now; I said it was the bag that I had seen, cloth or whatever they call it. I was very much troubled about my own brother, who was gone for a sailor, and I had been drinking rather more than what I should, and I really cannot tell what I did say.
Q. Was it on the evening that he was there? - It was in the morning, and I drank more than what I should, because I could not do my business at all after.

Q.
Therefore you don't know of your own knowledge that that was his bag? - No; nor I cannot swear that it was his bag, nor I never saw it opened no more than what the mother said.
Court. You swore positively to this bag before the Lord Mayor, and I am confident if you had been in liquor, as you say, you would not have been examined at all there.

Woodman. I was the person that went with this bag, and I said, is your name Simmons? to the mother-in-law; she said yes; I said directly, is your daughter at home? I come just to ask a simple question; I untied my handkerchief and I opened this bag, and I asked the mother-in-law if she knew this bag, that was all I said.
Q. How came you to go to the mother-in-law against these people? - I only went to get the bag identified. I don't know whether it was the mother or no, but I was directed by my brother officers.

Court to Woodman. What did you say to her to induce her to go with you? - What I said to her was this, when I asked about the bag the mother said she could swear to it; and this woman came out of a little back room, and she said, I can swear to that little black bag.
Q. Did you tell her what she was going to swear about? - I did not.
Johnson. This is the key of Simmons's own door, which I found upon him.
Mr. Knowlys. Do you sometimes carry a key of your door in your pocket? - I do.
Q. What is the reward if a man is convicted of a burglary? - I don't know that ever I received it.
Q. How long have you been a constable? - Five or six years.
Q. You don't know what the reward is? - I have been told it is forty pounds.
Q. Then if one man is convicted and forty pounds got by it, what is got if two men are convicted by it? - Double; that was not my intention of shewing the key.
Prisoner Simmons. I leave it to my Counsel.
The prisoner Simmons called three witnesses, who gave him a good character.
Prisoner Booth. I leave it to my Counsel.

Both
Not GUILTY .
Tried by the second London Jury before
Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

569.
ISAAC BOTHROW
was indicted for
that he, on the 17th of December , unlawfully, unjustly, and contrary to the duty of his office, did extort money under false pretences .

JOHN POWELL MILLER
sworn.
I served my time to a watch finisher.

Q. How do you get your livelihood now? - By a clerkship; I was clerk to Mr. Lucy, agent for the East India Company; I am not at present; I was clerk to
Mrs.
Macqueen's
, No. 128, in the Minories; I was standing in Mrs. Macqueen's shop the other side of the counter about eight days before Christmas, the prisoner came into the shop; his brother stood with him; he came in and says, Mrs. Macqueen I want some money; says she, Bothrow, I have done no business this lottery, and I a cannot give you any, as I told you before; he said he knowed that she had done business in that lottery, and that I was clerk to her, and that it lay in his power to take me away, or something to that purpose.

Q. When did this happen? - About eight days before Christmas last. With that Mrs. Macqueen says,
John Miller
, give him a crown. I put my hand into my right hand waistcoat pocket, and he made answer and said, Ma'am, I never had less than a guinea of you; she said, it is not in my power to give him a guinea now, so give him a crown; and before I gave it into his hand he said cannot you let me have half a guinea; says I, Bothrow, I have got no more about me; I told him I had not got half a guinea; he took the crown and he went about his business.
Q. What did you give him the crown for? - Out of fear; because he said I had done business that lottery.
Q. That he might not take you up as a vagrant? - Yes.
Q. How soon did you bring forward this prosecution? - From the day before Fast day, after the English lottery.
Q. When did it end? - In April.

Q. Then you let all that time pass without commencing any prosecution? - The 27th of January, the day before fast day, he faced me at the bottom of the Minories, and he touched me on the shoulder; his brother was present with him; he says to me, I want to speak with you; he said he had particular orders from the Lord Mayor to take me wherever he met me; with that I asked him for what? and he said it was on the lottery business, that his daughter had done some numbers with me; so I says, Bothrow, recollect I gave you a crown just before Christmas; he says d-n that crown, it is nothing, if you have got ever a friend to send for I will take you into a public house. He would not take me any where about the neighbourhood, he took me to the City Arms, and I sent a person for a friend; the friend did not come, and he said he would take me over to the Compter: he took me over to the Compter and gave charge of me, and I remained there from Thursday evening about five o'clock till Saturday about one, and he told me before that that he would let me go only so many people see him take me out of the Compter about one, and he says, Miller, it is, stasb, I am satisfied, and I shall tell you what to say when you come before the Lord Mayor; he tells me to say, that a woman gave charge of me to him on account of insuring; then, says he, you will be acquitted: and he had money for that, but I cannot bring the people forward on the business. I was acquitted before the Lord Mayor.
Q. How soon after this did you bring forward the prosecution? - Directly afterthis; because I was afraid of being stopped again.
Q. What was the day you brought forward the prosecution? - I believe it was in the month of April, to the best of my knowledge.

Mr. Knapp. You have told my Lord and gentlemen of the Jury, that you first of all was a watch finisher, and then you became clerk to Mr. Lucy, and now you are not in his employ? - Because he has no employ for me.
Q. But you have been employed by Mrs. Macqueen as her clerk in the lottery business, at an unlicensed lottery-office? - I suppose it to be such.
Court. Has your mistress ever paid you that money again? - No, never; it has been deducted out of my book by a gentleman that was at Mrs. Macqueen's office, that acted as master there.
Q. Then by your master or mistress you have been allowed the money? - Yes.
Q. Then it was no extortion on you?
Not GUILTY .
Tried by the second London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

570.
MARY HOWARD
was indicted for
that she, on the 6th of September , one ounce and a half of silver, value 7s. the goods of
Peter Bateman
, by a certain ill disposed person unknown, then lately before stolen, did receive, well knowing the same to be stolen .

JOHN CAVE
sworn.

I am a goldsmith; I live No. 3, Aldgate; I stopped the silver; it was offered to me by a girl, and I had some suspicion of its being stolen; I asked who it belonged to? and the girl said that she would go fetch who it belonged to; I kept the silver, and the prisoner at the bar came and claimed the silver; she came by herself and demanded the silver that I had stopped; I told her I thought it was very suspicious, and I certainly should not let her have the silver till I had made sufficient enquiry about the manufacturer. She went away; I kept the silver; that was on Saturday, the 6th of this month; on Thursday by making enquiries in the trade I found out the owner of it, Mr. Bateman. I sent it out by a person about the town; I gave it to
Richard Stocker
, he is a servant of mine; I think I should know it again, but he is here. The prisoner called two or three times during that period to enquire whether it was owned, and the last time by the order of the prosecutor I charged an officer with her.

RICHARD STOCKER
sworn.
I am a constable. I produce the silver.
Q. Did you receive any silver of Mr. Cave? - Yes.
Q. Should you know that silver again? - Yes, I delivered it to the constable, Tipper.
Q. Was you the person that carried it about? - Yes.
Q. Who owned it? - Mr. Peter Bateman; I never left it out of my own hands.

PETER BATEMAN
sworn.

On last Wednesday was a fortnight, I was informed that a person wanted to speak to me in my dwelling house; when I came in there, the last witness was present, and he asked me whether I knew any thing of this silver that he produced there to me? As soon as I see it, I said, yes; I was conscious that the silver came out of our manufactory; I knew it by the particular pieces, because it was all in pieces; but I said I would call my nephew, who was better acquainted with it than myself, because he was always distributing it to the workmen; it is no difficult matter for a workman to know his own work. We have our own sletting mills, and it is about a month since one of these rolls broke; we put in a new one, and theyhappened to be what we call cross cut; one of these pieces that were produced has the impression on it of the cross cut, and were statted in these rolls that had not been in above a fortnight. There are six ounces, but we swear to a certainty of an ounce and a half. I swear to one piece that is cross cut; I have evidence to make out the rest.

Q. Before it was produced to you, how long might it have been missing? - I cannot tell only that of the cross cut. On the evening of that same day, Mr. Stocker called on me again to know whether we wished the prisoner stopped, because she had been there to demand it again that day. I said, by all means; he waited on me the next day, and told me she was stopped, and desired me to come down to the City Arms.

CHARLES WARE
sworn.
I am a servant to Mr. Bateman.

Q. Have you ever seen the silver which Mr. Bateman spoke of just now? - I see it when it was produced before the Lord Mayor, at the Mansion-house. It is the property of Mr. Bateman? I made the tools that it was drawn in, I have got some in my pocket to correspond.
Q. Do you know the piece that has the cross cut? - No; I know some of the other pieces, that were drawn in the tools that I have with me.
Q. Has every workman in the trade different tools? - Different tools of their own making.
Q. Do you make your own tools? - Yes.
Q. Then you can swear to some? - Yes.
Q. What is the value of what you can swear to? - Three or four pieces.
Tipper. I produce some silver; I got it of Mr. Cave.
Cave. It is the same as Stocker brought it in; it was put on the counter, and I gave it to Mr. Tipper.
Tipper. I have kept it till now.

Q. To Bateman. What account did the girl give of it? - When I came down to the City Arms, that a man, who prosessed himself to be a mate of a ship, that she had lain with two nights, in Dark-house-lane gave it her.

Q. Did she tell you his name? - She did not know his name; she said, that she went on board a vessel with him, lying at Chetter quay on Wednesday, and that they drank together, and that the Thursday afterwards he came to the Green Man, and gave her this silver, and she got up on Thursday morning; she did not lie with him on Thursday night; and went down to the vessel to seek him, and the vessel was gone. On this information we went to the Green Man, in Dark-house-lane, and there found she had been there with a man, but they could not say who he was; but they said, that she lay there on Thursday. I went, in hopes that we had got in a train of finding out the thief.
Q. Has she always kept to the same story? - She has; but we have done all we can to find it out, but we find it was a false one.
Q. Look at the silver? - This is the piece that is cross cut; here is another piece, that I have compared with our tongs, which every piece has the impression on it.
Ware. I can swear to these three pieces from the tools that I made to draw them.
Q. What may be the value of all that you can swear to? - Seven shillings and six-pence.

Prisoner. I went with Mr. Bateman to the house in Darkhouse-lane, and I told him that I slept with that man. Iwas with that man, as I told him; and I said to him, you will not treat me ungenteel, and on Thursday morning he untied his silk handkerchief, and gave me that, and said, he had given good money for it to take it abroad, to make some trinkets. I kept it till Saturday night, when I went to an acquaintance's house, to know if she could tell me where to sell it; and she sent her girl with it to this gentleman's. He stopped it, and I went for it; and he said, he could not deliver the property. I called for it on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday; on Wednesday they told me they had found an owner; I said, I hope you will not let the gentleman have the property, for it is mine. I went on Thursday morning, and they took me into custody; I came honestly by it. I have nobody to speak to my character only women of the town, whose characters I would not wish to bring before you, that I am not connected with.
Not GUILTY .
Tried by the second London Jury before
Mr. RECORDER.
